title: Health Care Staff
description: In 2010, China was to dispatch a 27-staff health care team to Mauritania, in addition to pharmaceuticals and medical consumables (Project ID#12532). Mauritanian Health Minister Cheikh Ould Horma signed a two-year renewable convention on the health assistance with Chinese Ambassador to Mauritania Zhang Xun. The health-care personnel will assist local doctors in the hospitals of the capital city, Nouakchott, eastern Kiffa and Selibaby on the River Senegal, as well as in research centres. It is unclear if the team arrived.
sources: http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=APASENE020100610e66a0008i&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Factiva, International media report
factiva_sources: http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=APASENE020100610e66a0008i&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Factiva, International media report

title: Port of Friendship expansion project
description: In 2008, China and Mauritania signed an agreement to extend the Nouakchott Port, also known as the Port of Friendship (PANPA), by 900 meters. China's Ex-Im Bank will be funding the projection within a preferential loan of 2 billion Chinese yuan (roughly $295 million USD). The port will be built by a Chinese state-owned company, China Communications Construction Company Ltd., and should be completed within 36 months. The terms of the loan include it being refundable in 20 years, five years of grace period, and an interest rate of 2 percent. The project includes a petroleum berth, a water break point, and a 5 km dyke along the port in order to protect infrastructure. The goal of the project is to bring increased volume to the port region. The project commenced in January of 2009, launched by Mauritanian President Mohamed Ould Abdel Aziz and Chinese vice foreign minister, Zhai Jun. It appears that the project is untied.

title: Interest Free Loan for Hospital
description: In May 2001, a Chinese economic and trade delegation signed economic accords on cooperation and debt reduction with the Angolan government during a three-day visit to Luanda. The Chinese government extended an interest-free line of credit totaling about $6 million. Angola's Deputy Minister of Foreign Affairs, George Chicoty, signed the agreements with China's Vice Minister of External Trade and Economic Cooperation, Zhang Xiang. It was inaugurated in February 2006.

title: Debt Remission
description: In May 2001, a Chinese economic and trade delegation promised to dismiss about 10 percent of Angola's $80 million external debt to China during a three-day visit to Luanda.The status of the debt forgiveness is uncertain.

title: Food Aid
description: On May 17, 2001, the Angolan government received more than $600,000 in aid from China, aimed to alleviate the sufferings of the 115,000 people displaced by the heavy floods earlier this year. Angolan Minister of Assistance and Social Reintegration Albino Malungo spoke at the handover ceremony. The aid included 100 tons of rice, 24,000 tins of beef and luncheon meat, cooking utensils, and other daily necessities, and was distributed in Bie Province.
sector: Humanitarian and Disaster Relief and Preparation

title: Economic and Trade Development Center
description: In 2007, Li Zhaoxing, Chinese Foreign Minister, went on a 7-nation tour, stopping in Benin to sign a variety of agreements and attend the launching ceremony of a new Chinese trade and economic development center in Benin. In 2008, construction began on Benin's Chinese Economy and Trade Development Center. The center is located in Cotonou's Ganhi Business Center and is scheduled to be completed within 2008, becoming a high-end business center integrating exhibition, shopping, storage, business meetings, accommodations, and catering services. The Zhejiang Tianshi International Economic and Technological Cooperation Co., Ltd., was responsible for construction and will manage the center for the first 50 years. In 2009, the center was launched with the Benin China Merchandise Show. The facility ultimately cost 50 million Yuan, with a land area of 9,700 square meters and construction area of 6,891 square meters. The building is 5 stories. It is unclear exactly what the commitment year was, but it appears that it was 2008.
sector: Trade, Tourism, Banking and Financial Services

title: Donation to Flood Victims
description: On May 7, 2001, the Red Cross Society of China donated $20,000 dollars to the Red Cross Society of Angola to alleviate the sufferings of the Angolan people affected by heavy rains and floods in the western and southern parts of the country. Chinese Ambassador to Angola Jiang Yuande attended the handover ceremony.
sector: Humanitarian and Disaster Relief and Preparation

title: Loan
description: The Chinese government extended a US$50 million loan to the Angolan government. This was announced during a meeting between the Angolan deputy external relations minister, Jorge Chicoty, and the Chinese minister of foreign trade and economic cooperation, Shi Guangsheng in May of 2001. Further details and conditions are not known.

title: Judicial training
description: In 2001, Attorney General Domingos Culolo said Angolan magistrates would soon undergo training in China under the terms of an agreement signed in 2000. The accord provides, among other things, for the training of personnel, the exchange of delegations, and mutual assistance. The status of the training is uncertain.

title: Oil refinery
description: On January 16, 2001, China announced that it would take part in the construction of a new oil refinery in Lobito during Chinese Foreign Minister Tang Jiaxuan's visit to Angola. In March 2006, the president of Sonangol and the vice president of Sinopec signed a partnership to develop the refinery. The $3.5 billion project was expected to have a capacity to process 200,000 barrels/day, in which Sonangol held 70% and Sinopec 30%, was to start operations in 2010. The technical development of the project had been awarded in 2000 to Korea's Samsung, but a lack of funding kept the project from starting. In May 2012, the refinery was still incomplete. An updated projection estimated production at 120,000 barrels/day in the refinery's first stages, and eventually increase to 200,000 barrels/day.

description: On January 16, 2001, Chinese Minister Tang Jiaxuan committed a contribution of 200 million yuan in office furniture for the Angolan chancellory.

title: Computers and Sewing Machines
description: In October 2001, China's Ambassador to Angola, Jiang Yuande, delivered 10 computers and 40 sewing machines to the Popular Movement for the Liberation of Angola policy party headquarters in Luanda.

title: Emergency Humanitarian Aid following Earthquake
description: On May 23, 2003 the Chinese Ministry of Commerce announced that China would offer emergency humanitarian aid worth 5 million yuan to the earthquake-hit Algeria. It is unclear how the Ministry of Commerce is involved in the project. On that same day, China sent an earthquake rescue team of 30 personnel to Algeria. The team was headed by a deputy director of the China Seismological Bureau, and provided aid for the disaster victims. The team carried 3 search dogs and rescue equipment. On May 30, the team successfully accomplished their mission and returned to China.
sector: Humanitarian and Disaster Relief and Preparation

title: Police Station
description: In December of 2009 the Chinese community in Gaborone volunteered to build a police post in the Block Three industrial areas as an effort to help the police combat crime in the area. The area, which hosts many Chinese-owned businesses, has been targeted by criminals. Deputy Chief of the Chinese embassy in Botswana Gou Haodong said they may build the police post in the area around Oriental Plaza. Upon completion, the Chinese community will donate furniture and office equipment.

title: Agricultural training in China
description: The Yuan Longping High-Tech Agriculture, a state-owned company that researches hybrid rice, plans to train 5,000 foreigners, establish 10 breeding centers and expand overseas cultivation bases to 10,000 hectares in 10 years. So far it trained more than 2,000 government officials and agrotechnicians from 50 countries through 30 training courses. Antonio Mende Tavares, an agricultural official from Guinea-Bissau who was here for a three-month training, said that China and Guinea-Bissau would deepen their collaboration in hybrid-rice cultivation next year. And in the following three years, the planting area would expand from the initial 200 hectares to 1,000 hectares. The project is possibly related to ID#805.

title: Preferential loan for Cotton Mill
description: In March of 2000, the Export-Import Bank of China approved a preferential loan worth 76.5 million Yuan to finance a cotton mill in the African country of Benin. The factory is expecting to ease a growing shortage of cotton textiles in central and western Africa. It is unclear exactly how the funds were used, but the project appears to be untied. The loan was the second batch under a 150 million RMB yuan (US$ 18 million) preferential lending package signed between the governments of the two countries in 1998.

title: Telecommunications construction and supply contract
description: ZTE Telecommunications was awarded a $40 million contract in the first quarter of 2003 to build two CDMA wireless local loops (WLL) for a total of 240,000 power lines in Algeria. A Chinese news source reported that the total equipment and installation costs would be $47 million--$40 million is reportedly being underwritten with a 6.5 year tender by Chinese export credit agency Sinosure to Algeria Telecom agreed on in January 2004, and it is also reported that the Industrial and Commercial Bank of China (ICBC) and European financial institution Societe Generale are jointly funding the project. The project was reportedly completed for just $32 million however the precise date of completion is unknown, as are the specific loan terms and the precise commitment by ICBC. The completion of these WLLs led to another contract signing on January 1, 2005, in which ZTE will build a CDMA network focused primarily in the provinces of Tizi Ouzou, Bouira and Bejaia, that will bring total coverage in Algeria to 95%. See ID# 14734.

title: Loan for medium and low cost houses
description: On December 8, 2004 Botswana and China signed a P117 million loan agreement. The Minister of Finance and Development Planning, Baledzi Gaolatlhe, said the amount would enable the Botswana Housing Corporation (BHC) to construct 725 medium and low cost houses in Maun, Jwaneng, Gaborone, Lobatse, Francistown and Gaborone. The loan is payable in 15 years at an interest rate of three per cent per annum with a grace period of four years. Other sources reported that The China Overseas Engineering Group Co., Ltd (COVEC) built 424 affordable houses in 2005, which was financed by a concessional loan from the Chinese government. Sketchy button was applied due to uncertainty of the projects matching up. It is unclear what the current status of the project is.

title: Grant for human resource training and purchase of equipment
description: In December of 2004, Botswana and China signed a P117million loan agreement, which was to be used for low cost housing. The Minister of Finance and Development Planning, Baledzi Gaolatlhe said Beijing had also offered the government of Botswana a grant amounting to over P2 million to be used for human resource training and purchase of equipment for the project. The construction of the housing was to be carried out by the Botswana Housing Corporation (BHC). In a 2008 report issued by the Embassy of China in Botswana, it was revealed that short-term training opportunities are offered to Botswana by China, lasting from one week to a year, covering areas of information, agriculture, business and commerce, industry, sport, military, etc. In 2005, 41 officials and experts went to China for training. In 2006, China provided about 150 such opportunities to Botswana. In 2007, China provided more than 160 quotas to Botswana. See project #21 for related project.

title: Multi-Purpose Youth Centre
description: In 2004, Chinese Ambassador to Botswana, Difu Lin, mentioned that China had provided Botswana with a free/low interest loan for the construction of a multipurpose youth centre. The project began on October 8, 2009 and was expected to be complete by July 2011. A local Chinese source reported that the project would cost US$9.5 million and would be located between the Madirelo Training Centre and Gaborone Dam. The report also stated that Zhongding International Engineering Company would be implementing the project. Chinese State Councilor Liu Yandong, accompanied by Gladys Kokorwe, the Minister of Youth, Sports, and Culture of Botswana, visited the Gaborone Multifunctional Youth Center on November 5, 2011 but it is unclear if the project was completed at the time.

description: In 2006, China and Benin agreed on an interest-free loan to the African country worth 30 million yuan (2.9 million euros, 3.8 million dollars). It is unclear how the funds were used. Li Zhaoxing, China's Foreign Minister, was present at the signing. The project was likely untied. This project is affiliated with the Chinese writing off a sum of Benin's debt and another aid package to improve administration and transport infrastructure. Neither amount has been given.

title: Chinese Medical Team
description: In 2005, China and Botswana signed a protocol on sending medical teams. Under this protocol, the Chinese government agreed to send a team consisting of 41 medical staff and 5 support staff for three years. The financial value for this project and current status is unknown. Staff note: Until China sends a second medical team, we cannot say this is a recurring project. Therefore it has been classified as OOF-like.

title: Interest-free Loan
description: The Vice Premier of the State Council of the People's Republic of China, Mr. Huang Ju paid a three day Official Visit to Botswana from 19th to 21st November in 2005. During the visit, the Vice Premier held official talks with His Excellency the President of the Republic of Botswana, Mr. Festus Gontebanye Mogae. The two Governments signed three cooperation Agreements, namely; 1.) A Protocol Between the Government of the Republic of Botswana and the Government of the People's Republic of China on the Chinese Medical Team to Botswana. China to send a medical team of 46 members, comprising 41 medical staff and 5 support staff to work in Botswana for three years from the date of their arrival. 2.) Agreement on Economic and Technical Cooperation Between the Government of the Republic of Botswana and the Government of the People's Republic of China. China agreed to provide the Botswana Government with an interest-free loan of RMB Yuan 30,000,000.00 within ten years from 1st January 2006 to 31st December 2015. 3.) Framework Agreement Between the Government of the Republic of Botswana and the Government of the People's Republic of China on Provision of Concessional Loans by China to Botswana. China to provide a concessional loan of RMB Yuan 150,000,000.00 which shall be utilized to implement projects to be agreed upon consultations between the two sides.
sources: http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=AFNWS00020051128e1bs002s5&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Factiva, International media report

title: Eximbank loan for housing project
description: On July 17, 2006, China and Botswana signed an agreement to renew a housing project started in 1998 with a new concessional loan of 55 million BWP. The project involves the construction of 293 housing units in Gaborone. The project, implemented by the China National Overseas Engineering Corporation, included low and mid-range residential single-layer brick structures, water supply and drainage, and well as outdoor walls, and was started on January 26, 2006. The loan has a grant element of 33 percent, a 3 percent interest rate, and a ten-year repayment period. The current status of this project cannot be found. STAFF_NOTES: It is unclear how the grant element was calculated for the article written about this project, however it would be difficult to achieve a grant element of 33% with those loan attributes if part of this loan was not given as a grant.

description: In 2006, Guangdong Huarun paints Chemical Co. Ltd. provided interior and exterior wall coatings to be used in the Office Building of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs of Benin. The company was appointed by the Chinese Ministry of Commerce as an aid project between China and Benin. Huarun Paints Chemical signed an agreement with the contractor in December of 2006, effective January of 2007. The paints were shipped in January of 2007 to be used. title: May 2009 Grant (Preceded December 2009 Grant)
description: The Chinese government has given Botswana a grant amounting to 20 million yuan (P19.2 million) to help Botswana implement some of its priority projects in National Development Plan (NDP 10). The agreement follows another one amounting to 10 million yuan that was signed between China and Botswana in May this year. Matambo said consultations were still ongoing regarding projects to be implemented with the earlier grant.

title: Grant for National Development Plan
description: The Chinese government has given Botswana a grant amounting to 20 million yuan to help Botswana implement some of its priority projects in National Development Plan. The agreement was signed by Minister of Finance and Development Planning, Kenneth Matambo and Chinese Ambassador to Botswana, Liu Huanxing. The agreement follows another one amounting to 10 million yuan that was signed between China and Botswana in May this year. Matambo said consultations were still ongoing regarding projects to be implemented with the earlier grant.

title: Construction Primary Schools
description: On December 3, 2007 China and Botswana signed a 10 million RMB (8.1 million Pula) grant agreement on the construction of two primary schools one in Serowe and one in Maun in the Ngamiland district of Botswana. Chinese Ambassador to Botswana Ding Xiaowen and Botswana Finance Minister Baledzi Gaolathe signed on behalf of their respective governments. A handover ceremony for the schools was held on September 25, 2009.

title: Morupule B Power Expansion Project
description: The Government of Botswana (GoB) successfully mobilized the required external financial resources for the Morupule B Power Station from the Industrial and Commercial Bank of China and Standard Bank Consortium (ICBC-SB) and the IBRD. ICBC-SB signed a 20 year loan agreement for US $825 million on the 15th June 2009 and IBRD’s Board is expected to consider the Partial Credit Guarantee and the loan for the project in October 2009. African Development Bank funding is required to close the financing gap of the project. The World Bank website reports the the project is expected to be complete in June of 2014, but there have been reports that the project has stalled due to safety and health violations. The Botswanan Ministry of Minerals, Energy and Water Resources (MMWER) and the Department of Environmental Affairs has received reports that the CNEEC contracting manager Jianio Caiyi and two other company project supervisors allegedly fled the country last week (June 2012) leaving the Station Project Manager, Glenn Black, to clean up the mess. Black allegedly resigned soon after.

title: Benin's Biofuel Joint Venture
description: In 2010, the China Africa Development Fund agreed to buy the additional shares and convertible bonds to be issued by Hong Kong-listed Hua Lien International (Holding) Co. Ltd at an aggregate HK$390 million. The two parties signed an MoU in 2010. Under the MOU, the firm will sell 90 million additional shares at HK$0.6 apiece, representing HK$54 million in total consideration. It will also sell to the fund 5-year convertible notes for approximately HK$336 million. The additional shares would represent 7.21% of the existing issued share capital and approximately 6.72% of the entire enlarged issued shared capital. If all the convertible bonds are exercised, China Africa Development Fund will have a 34.23% stake in Hua Lien. The proceeds will be used entirely to launch a joint venture in the Republic of Benin a country in West Africa, in partnership with China Africa Development Fund and COMPLANT International Sugar Industry Co. Ltd, which holds a 24.03% stake in Hua Lien. Hua Lien will take a 65% stake in the joint venture, while China Africa Development Fund will hold a 25%, and COMPLANT will take 10%. The Benin joint venture will then be used as a vehicle to establish a Benin PC for engaging in Ethanol Biofuel business, targeting European Union and Africa as its major markets.

title: Confucius Institute at University of Botswana
description: A report made in February of 2010 stated that the Confucius Institute in the University of Botswana was officially launched in September of 2009 in order to continue educational advancement in the Chinese language, history and culture learning. 230 Botswana students have taken classes at the institute as of February 2010. STAFF_NOTES: Although this project does not specifically mention Chinese involvement, the Chinese have been involved in donations of language equipment and scholarships for students with it in the past. Since there is evidence of a relationship, the project remained in the database but without a financial amount.

title: Demining Equipment
description: On April 16, 2002, the Angolan and Chinese governments signed an accord for logistical and demining equipment for the Angolan Armed Forces. They would help the military personnel and impact the reopening of roads in the country. General Demostenes Amos Chilingutila, the Vice Minister of Defense for Angola, and Jian Yaunde, the Chinese Ambassador, signed the agreeement in Luanda. The equipment donated will include dormitories and catering equipment at $500,000 US dollars and demining equipment at $400,000 US dollars for a total commitment of $900,000. STAFF_NOTES: This project has a mix of clearly ODA information with humanitarian services and other military contributions. Since they are both in-kind contributions, the project is classified as ODA-like even though it is for the military. The gifts were not military in nature as they helped improve living situations and de-mining procedures.

title: Buying Goods for UNITA Soldiers
description: In July of 2002, China donated 5 million CNY to buy goods for UNITA soliders (National Union for the Total Independence of Angola) and their relatives, who are living in confinement areas. The Chinese deputy minister for Foreign Affairs talked with Angolan counterpart Toko Serao about the details, but they are unknown to open reports. Further details of the donation are uncertain. STAFF_NOTES: This project may be referring to prisoners of war, in which case it would not be military.
sector: Humanitarian and Disaster Relief and Preparation

title: Medicine, Equipment and Humanitarian Aid
description: Angolan President Jose Eduardo dos Santos received a message on July 18, 2002 sent by Chinese President Jiang Zemin, congratulating him on the re-establishment of peace in his country. The Chinese deputy minister for foreign affairs, Yang Wenchang, who arrived in Angola on July 16, presented the message to the Angolan president. Wenchang later announced the arrival of medicines in Luanda, 3,000 wheelchairs, tents and food. The donation, valued at approximately 300,000 dollars, was in response to the appeal made by the Angolan authorities to the international community for emergency assistance to the displaced persons, the UNITA soldiers and their families.

title: Computer donation
description: In 2002, Chinese Ambassador to Angola donated 19 computers to Angola's ruling Popular Movement for the Liberation of Angola (MPLA) political party. It is unclear how much the computers were worth or where they were ultimately used.

title: Tuberculosis Medicine
description: In June of 2003, the People's Republic of China was to donate medicines worth $300,000 US dollars to the Angolan Government to help with the shortage of TB-related drugs in public hospitals. The Angolan government had made a public appeal two years ago to help the people fight against tuberculosis. The medicines were to be handed over to the Health Minister, Albertina Hamukuaya, by the Chinese ambassador, Beisan Zhang. No additional information could be found regarding the completion of the donation.

title: Provision of CDMA fixed wireless network to government-owned Sierratel
description: In July of 2008, China signed an agreement to provide a concessional loan to Sierra Leonean telecommunication company Sierratel for $16.6 million USD in order to support a CDMA project. According to the Economic and Commercial Counselor at Freetown's Chinese Embassy, the project will provide Sierra Leone with an improved and efficient telecommunication system. The loan for this project, known as the Sierra Leone Rural and Sub-urban Telecommunication CDMA Network Project, will be financed by China's Ex-Im Bank and subsequently carried out by Chinese company Huawei Technologies. It is expected to be completed at the end of 2008, after which Huawei will provide technical support for one year. In April of 2009, Sierra Leonean President Ernest Bai Koroma launched the new telecom company. PPIAF-ID:241

title: Loan for Rebuilding Infrastructure (Benguela Railway, Luanda Airport, Luanda to Uíge Highway)
description: In March/April of 2005, the China International Fund (CIF) and the GRN signed a loan agreement with documents signed in both Hong Kong and Luanda. An initial amount of $2.9 billion US dollars was allocated for the war strewn country and construction projects (taking $2 billion of that money). These projects included reconstructing the Luanda airport and the construction of a new one (US$450 million), expansion and repairs to railway lines such as the Benguela railway line (US$300 million), cleaning the Luanda bay, a new sewage system for the capital, and others. While many of these projects began, in 2007, some had halted due to problems within CIF and the construction company, Beiya International Development Ltd. By the end of 2008, 80 percent of the initial US$2.9 billion disbursement had been spent on these projects. The loan overall was a low interest loan funded with providing Angolan oil. Project list individually:CONFIRMED: China contributed US$300 million in 2006 to begin the refurbishment of the Benguela Railway. Since 2006 sections of the railway have become operational, including the section that runs eastward to Huambo from Lobito, a distance of 423 km. The remainder of the project is expected to be completed in December of 2012. The entire project is expected to cost US$ 1.56 billion, but this funding does not all originate from Chinese sources. China Railway 20 Bureau Group Corp. has been the main contributor to the renovations.CONFIRMED: The new International Luanda Airport, located 30 kilometres from the Angolan capital, is being built by China International Fund Limited. The airport, which will cover an era of 5,000 hectares, will have two double runways. China gave US$ 450 million to the project. Although the project was scheduled to be concluded in 2010, one observer reported in 2011, 'apart from cranes, trucks, Chinese nationals, and a partial foundation, there was little evidence of serious work going on. 'CIF is a company that has no construction record or credentials,' a Chinese official said cynically. 'Largely they are brokers who get contracts from the Angolan government and sell them to other Chinese companies for huge profits.'CONFIRMED: Chinese state company China Road and Bridge Corporation (CRBC), is rebuilding 371 kilometers of the national road linking Kifangondo (Luanda), Caxito (Bengo), Uíge and Negage (Uíge) in Angola. The project, which began in December 2005, is estimated to cost US$211 million. The rebuilding project includes 12 bridges, 10 of which will be new, and requires over 200 aqueducts to be built. The project was expected to be done in June of 2008, but a PPIAF source states that the project was completed on July 25, 2008.CONFIRMED: The new bridge over the River Cunene, in Xangongo, Angola, built by the subsidiary of the China Road and Bridge Corporation (CRBC) is complete as of June 2009. The bridge, estimated to cost US$29 million, is 808 metres long and 11.64 metres wide and was built over two years and five months. The work was audited by Africon Gabenk BKS. The road between Ondjiva and Xangongo, covering 108 kilometers, was also built by CRBC for US$47 million and was completed as of June 2009.CONFIRMED: Around US$100 million dollars of the China credit line will be spent in the rehabilitation and equipping of various health posts in the central Huambo Province announced by Angolan Health minister Sebastiao Veloso in August of 2005. The mentioned sum will be used in the rehabilitation and equipping of the regional hospital, located in Huambo city and in the construction of two district hospitals.STAFF_NOTES:This project could benefit from splitting.

title: Infrastructure loan
description: In 2003, the Chinese government granted a loan to Angola worth roughly $300 million USD to be used in the rehabilitation of railway, electrical energy network, drinking water system and other areas. It is unclear exactly how the funds were used. Further details on the loan are unclear.

title: Journalist exchange
description: In 2004, six Angolan journalists with state-run media institutions left from Luanda for China for an interchange and study visit. The journalists will be in China for 15 days, visiting Beijing and Hong-Kong. The project was organized by the Chinese Embassy in Angola.

title: Interest-Free Loan
description: The Chinese government has decided to grant Angola a new loan worth 50 million yens, approximately 6.3m dollars, interest free, with a view to strengthening bilateral relations. The agreement was signed by Chinese Vice-Premier Zeng Peiyan and Angolan Prime Minister Fernando da Piedade Dias dos Santos. One source reported that the agreements were oil related and to be used for 'technical projects.'

title: Agricultural Donation
description: In 2005, China donated 46 containers (960 tons) of agricultural and other inputs worth roughly $1.0003 million USD to Angola. These containers are mainly for farmers of the northern Malanje province. The donation includes 150,000 hoes and handles, 159,000 axes, 218,697 cutlasses, 50 scythes, and 1,000 plows. Chinese Ambassador to Angola, Zhang Beisan, handed over the deal to the Social Welfare Deputy Minister Maria da Luz.

title: Marburg fever medicine
description: In 2005, the Chinese government offered to send in medical means worth 1 million Chinese Yuan in order to aid the efforts to combat the spread of the Marburg hemorrhagic fever in Angola. It is unclear if the funds were ever received, and if so, how they were used.

title: Telecommunications Networking--ZTE Corporation and Mundo Startel
description: (PPIAF) Supply of CDMA 2000 network to Angola's fixed-line telecom operator Mundo Startel. Following the completion, the network was to cover Angola's eight major provinces, and offer more advanced telecom services for customers, including voice, data; Political/Resource Considerations: Commercial; Total Project Cost: USD 69 Million; Project was verified as 'completed' by PPIAF-ID:11 or project ID# 907. PPIAF-ID:11 ZTE Corporation International (China) had signed an agreement with Mundo Startel, the Angolan fixed-line telecommunication utility, for the sale of telecommunications equipment. ZTE would invest US$400 million to build Angola's telecom network, upgrade the military telecommunications system, and construct a mobile phone factory.

title: Electrical network (Related to Project ID#65 and ID#66)
description: A complementary individual financing accord was signed in July of 2008 by the Angolan Finance minister, Jose Pedro de Morais, and the chairman of Eximbank, Li Ruogu. The accord concerns an agreement for funding of the project of rehabilitation and expansion of the electrical network of the cities of Dundo (Lunda Norte province) and Saurimo (Luanda Sul), estimated at around USD 50 million loan. OVERVIEW: New Exim Bank head, Li Ruogu, and José Pedro de Morais sign a “Complementary Individual Financing MOU”, which sees the disbursement of a separate US$134 million loan to three communal development projects in Angola. The terms of the loan are the same as the September 2007 Exim Bank loan. The credit will fund the modernisation of the electricity system in two towns in Lunda Norte and Luanda Sul provinces, the construction of a water treatment plant and canals in the Luanda area and a road upgrade projects in two other provinces. See Project ID#65 and ID#66 for the related projects described above.

title: Water projects
description: A complementary individual financing accord was signed in July of 2008 by the Angolan Finance minister, Jose Pedro de Morais, and the chairman of Eximbank, Li Ruogu. The protocol is designed for the rehabilitation of the residual waters treatment station in Quifangondo (Luanda), the construction of a distribution centre in Cacuaco district, as well as the execution of new house plumbing works, estimated at USD 28.798 million. title: Street Building (Related to Project ID#64 and ID#65)
description: A complementary individual financing accord was signed in July of 2008 by the Angolan Finance minister, Jose Pedro de Morais, and the chairman of Eximbank, Li Ruogu. It is designed to improve the streets of the cities of Caxito (Bengo), Uige and Negage (Uige), a contract estimated at around US$56 million. As of June 3, 2009, the Chinese company China Road and Bridge Corporation (CRBC) is rebuilding the national road that links the Angolan city of Uíge to the municipality of Maquela do Zombo. Reconstruction work on the road, as well as the Negage-Bungo section, began in 2008, is estimated to cost US$79.6 million and is due to be concluded in 2010. The minister for Public Works, Higino Carneiro, visited the project’s workshop along with directors from the Angolan National Roads Institute (INEA), the Mota-Engil group and officials from China’s CRBC. No verification that the project has been completed. OVERVIEW: New Exim Bank head, Li Ruogu, and José Pedro de Morais sign a “Complementary Individual Financing MOU”, which sees the disbursement of a separate US$134 million loan to three communal development projects in Angola. The terms of the loan are the same as the September 2007 Exim Bank loan. The credit will fund the modernisation of the electricity system in two towns in Lunda Norte and Luanda Sul provinces, the construction of a water treatment plant and canals in the Luanda area and a road upgrade projects in two other provinces. See Project ID#64 and ID#65 for the related projects described above.

title: Agricultural development
description: In 2009, Angola secured a $1.2 billion USD loan from China to be spent on developing its agricultural sector. The China Development Bank is responsible for funding the loan. The project aims to guarantee the supply of goods like coffee, sisal, sugar cane, and cotton, while creating jobs in rural and poor areas. The World Bank believes up to $8 billion USD more has not been publicized; many news reports said more than 1 billion was provided as a line of credit. The loan is to be repaid in oil exports to China and by awarding contracts for project to Chinese companies. How exactly the funds were used is unclear.

title: Loan for rebuilding roads
description: In 2010, the Export-Import Bank of China agreed to loan Angola $500 million USD to rebuild roads to help the African nation recover from a three-decade long civil war that ended in 2002. It is unclear how exactly the funds were used.

title: Donation to table tennis association
description: In 2010, China's Citic Construction company donated 300,000 Chinese Yuan to the Angolan Table Tennis Association to promote the developments of its events within Angola.STAFF_NOTES: Sports donations are part of the 'Culture and Recreation' part of aid classification (under Other Social Infrastructures and Activities). Since the in-kind contribution comes from a corporate SOE, it is labeled as CA + SOE.

description: (PPIAF-ID: 231) On October 28, 2007, Lou Qinjian, China's Deputy Minister of Information Industry, and Rwanda's State Minister in charge of Energy and Communication, Albert Butare, met at a ceremony in Kigali for the donation of $130,000 USD worth of telecom equipment donated to Rwanda by China's Huawei Technologies.

title: Reconstruction of an explosives plant at Chambishi copper mine
description: (PPIAF) China-based Beijing General Research Institute of Mining and Metallurgy (BGRIMM) and Nonferrous Corporation Africa (NFCA) said that they would reinvest $600,000 from the existing BGRIMM research trust fund of $4.4 billion to reconstruct the explosives plant at Chambishi copper mine which was destroyed in a blast in 2005 that killed up to 50 workers. It is unclear what the commitment year for this project is or if it has been implemented. PPIAF-ID:455

description: (PPIAF-ID:427) In 2003, China's Zhongyuan Petroleum Exploration Bureau, a subsidiary of Sinopec, explored Sudan's 3/7 Oil Area with the Tiki-1 Test Well with an investment of 1.3 million USD. The project is completed. The start and end dates are unknown.

title: Rehabilitation and expansion of network access
description: In 2005, China signed a contract to expand and upgrade CDMA2000 1X WLL network in Mali. The new contract will expand the existing network in Barmako and bring coverage to Mopti, Segou, Sikasso, and Tombouctou. The total project cost was $2.35 million, with a Chinese commitment of $1.41 million. The status of the project is uncertain. (PPIAF) Expand and upgrade CDMA2000 1X WLL network in the country. The new contract will expand the existing network in Bamako and bring coverage to the centres of Mopti, Segou, Sikasso and Tombouctou.; Political/Resource Considerations: Commercial; Total Project Cost: USD 2.35 Million; Chinese Commitment: USD 1.41 Million; PPIAF-ID:181

title: Rehabilitation of two power plants
description: (PPIAF) In 2004, China agreed to assist with the rehabilitation of two power plants, the Ginkang Hydropower Plant and Tinkisso Hydropower Plant. The Chinese contributed $2 million USD toward the projects. It appears that the projects were completed in 2006. The Hunan Construction Engineering Group Corp. was responsible for the projects. The timeline for construction is unclear. PPIAF-ID:152

title: Mining rights and Factory
description: On June 9, 2007 China Sun Group High-Tech Co. entered into a contract with Shengbao Group and South African Shengbao Mining Enterprises, in which DLX (subsidiary of Sun Group) bought 80% of the rights to a 35 sq. km DRC cobalt ore mine owned by Shengbao for $2,000,000. DLX also provided equipment and engineering staff for the mine and agreed to produce no less than twenty tons of ore per day. In 2007, China Sun Group High-Tech Co. set up their own factory in Kantaga to process the ore from the mine. The exact end date and costs for the factory are yet unknown. PPIAF-ID:343

title: Gottera-Wolo Sefer Road
description: On December 17, 2003, Addis Ababa Major Arkebe Oqubay and Chinese Foreign Minister Li Zhaoxing inaugurated the newly-built Ethio-China Friendship road. The 2.2 km-long road, once the Gotera-Wollo Sefer Road, was constructed with Chinese government aid. The total cost of the project was $4.52 million, and the Chinese committed $2.94 million.

title: Exploration of gold
description: (PPIAF-ID:438) In 2007, Tianjin North China Geological Exploration Bureau signed an agreement with Sudan Geological Bureau to explore gold in a 6000 km2 field. The exploration was officially launched on May 17, 2007. The Chinese side invested 30 million Yuan and would own 55% of the venture. As the first phase, the exploration will last for 3 years, and can be extended for another 2 years. The project was completed. The end date and location are unknown.

title: Zinder Water Supply Project
description: In 2002, the China Railway Construction Corp. constructed the Zinder Water Supply Project in Niger with aid from the Chinese government. The network links of 10.3 km links twelve wells, and has a water supply canal of 25 km. According to a PPIAF consultant, the Chinese commitment for this project is $4 million, while the total project cost is $8.55 million. The exact start and end dates are still unknown.; PPIAF-ID:197

title: Loan for Grand Poubara Hydroelectric Project
description: In 2008, the Chinese government agreed to extend a concessionary loan to Gabon to fund the hydropower project. The entire project amounted to $398 billion US dollars, but the amount that China provided is unclear. The agreement was signed by Gabonese Finance Minister Paul Toungui and China's ambassador Hxue Jinwei. The loan has a 3% interest rate over its 20-year term, with a seven-year grace period. The Grand Poubara hydroelectric project is linked to a $3 billion iron ore mining project at Belinga. The hydropower plants will add approximately 6,000 jobs. The entire construction process will be completed in 54 months; construction officially began on November 15, 2008.

title: Housing shortage reduction
description: In 2011, China partnered with the Ivory Coast government in the construction sector to reduce the housing shortage. In an August 2011 meeting with a Chinese construction company, Ivory Coast Prime Minister Guillume Soro called for concerted efforts with the Ivory Coast Construction and Housing Company (SICOGI) to ensure that the majority of the people live in decent houses. The status of the project is uncertain.

title: GSM mobile telecommunication project
description: (PPIAF-ID:51) In 2004, Huawei signed a contract with Burundi to implement the 6 month Burundi GSM mobile telecommunication project. The project includes three parts: GSM mobile network extension from original 30000 users to 60000 users for the nation's capital Bujumbura and its neighborhood, and fixed access switching in three cities. The China Exim Bank provided 7.91 million USD financing for the 9.31 million USD project. The project was launched at the end of the first quarter of 2006.

title: 65% stake in oil and gas exploration block 20
description: (PPIAF) On June 25th, 2005, China National Petroleum Company signed a contract with Mauritania, becoming the 65% operator of Block 20 in an oil and gas exploration in Mauritania. CNPC will fund the exploration costs. Baraka Petroleum of Australia owns the remaining 35% stake. The block covers more than 10,000 square kilometers and is considered one of the most promising onshore areas of the Mauritanian Coastal Basin. It is located about 180 km southeast of Chinguetti. The project appears to be tied. In 2007, CNPC's first wildcat in Mauritania was declared a failure after two poor production tests. PPIAF-ID:389

title: Establish a manganese processing plant in Kabwe
description: (PPIAF) Chiman Manufacturing's mine was the first manganese mine opened in Zambia. Chiman Manufacturing Ltd. started processing manganese in 2007. Chiman Manufacturing had constructed a processing plant eight kilometres from the mine, and invested $10 million USD into the plant. Commercial production was to start in May of 2007 with 16,000 tons expected to be produced during the year. PPIAF-ID:456

title: Construction of the bridge between Khartoum and the Sudanese-Egyptian border
description: (PPIAF-ID:249) In 2004, the China National Petroleum Corporation (CNPC) granted Sudan 10 million USD to construct the Merowe Bridge across the Nile River towards Aswan Dam. The bridge is 440 meters long and 20 meters wide. The bridge links Merowe on the eastern bank of the Nile River to Karima on the other side. Construction of the bridge, which started in May of 2004, was implemented by China 's Jilin International Economic and Technical Corporation. The bridge was formally complete on December 31, 2007, and opened to traffic on January 17, 2008.

title: Zina-Makary oil block
description: In April 2009 Yan Chang Logone Development Co. Ltd. signed a $62 million production sharing contract (PSC) with Cameroon in for the Zina-Makary oil block, situated in the country's Far North region. The joint China-Cameroon venture firm initially invested $62 million in April 2009. An oil well was successfully drilled in July 2011. Yan Chang Logone Chief Executive Officer Wei Wang commented publicly about the drill's success. PPIAF-ID:348 STAFF_NOTES: Yan Chang Logone Development Co. Ltd. is a subsidiary of an SOE so it is classified as such.

description: In 2007, Shanghai Construction began construction on the Gotera Intersection Bridge in Addis Ababa where 4 backbone roads meet. The total project cost and Chinese commitment was $12.71 million. The project was inaugurated on June 1, 2009. The interchange is 8.1 km in total and lays on 40 hectares of land.PPIAF-ID:122

title: Revive Mhangura Copper Mines, Lomagundi Smelting and Mining and Sanyati Copper Fields
description: On July 13, 2006, the Zimbabwe Mining Development Corporation (ZMDC), the state-run mining company, signed an agreement with the Chinese company Wambao Shinex to form a joint-venture company called Zimbao Mining Ventures; this new company would revive Mhangura Copper Mines, Lomagundi Smelting and Mining, and Sanyati Copper Fields. Aside from financing a geological survey that found sizable deposits of iron-ore at Sanyati Fields, Zimbao would be used to develop the new Chimanimani Gold project as well. As part of the agreement, ZMDC would receive a 49% share in the new company while Zambao would own the remaining 51%; the total Chinese commitment to the project was US$14 million. According to a non-media report dated in June 2007, the mobilization of machinery for the mining joint-venture had already begun. Additional research in to finish dates for the project and updates on projects being implemented by Zimbao was unsuccessful.

description: (PPIAF) In 2002, China Machine-Building International Corporation (CMIC) agreed to undertake three phases of the Project for Rehabilitation and Extension of the Electrical System in Luanda. CMIC completed the first phase of the project. The project value for the first phase was $15 million USD, financed by China's Export-Import Bank. PPIAF-ID:5

title: Dutlwe-Morwamosu Road [Same as Letlhakeng-Kang Phase 2]
description: Botswana's Public Procurement Asset Disposal Board approved the tender titled 'Construction of Letlhakeng-Kang Road Section II from Dutlwe to Morwamosu Request to negotiate with the contract, China State Construction Engineering Corporation' on October 06, 2004. China Construction Botswana Ltd completed the construction of the Dutlwe-Morwamosu road project. The opening ceremony was held in Boonen, a District Dutlwe. The project consists of 95.74 km of the main road (9.7 meters wide), 7.07 kilometers of roads (7.0 meters wide), 31 km of connecting roads and 119 culverts. The exact date of completion is not reported, but the article was published on December 7, 2010. This section of road was Phase 2 of the Letlhakeng-Kang road project(PPIAF) Dutlwe - Morwamosu Road Project is situated in the western part of Botswana and passes through Kweneng, Southern and Kgalagadi Districts. The area's main economic activity is subsistence agriculture, comprising principally the raising of cattle; Political/Resource Considerations: Political; Chinese Commitment: USD 16.7 Million; PPIAF-ID:47(PPIAF) Letlhakeng-Kang (Phase 2) road project.; Political/Resource Considerations: Political; Total Project Cost: USD 40 Million; Chinese Commitment: USD 18.6 Million; PPIAF-ID:46

title: License for Block 2 in the Gulf of Guinea Joint Development Zone (JDZ)
description: In 2006, SINOPEC secured a production and sharing contract to develop Block 2 in the Gulf of Guinea Joint Development Zone (JDZ), an area of the ocean floor lying between Nigeria and Sao Tome. According to the terms of the deal, Nigeria will receive 60% of all income from the oil and gas in the zone, while Sao Tome Principe will receive 40%. The signing bonus paid by SINOPEC was $71 million. According to a PPIAF source, the total project cost and Chinese commitment for this project are both $17.75 million. In June of 2011, a 12-month extension was signed on this project.

title: Kipsigak-Serem-Shamakhokho road project
description: A project to build a 54-km-long highway, starting in Kipsigak in Rift Valley Province and ending in Shamakhokho in Western Province, was agreed upon between China and Kenya in 1999. On July 17, 2001 the two governments signed a concessional loan agreement to finance the project. It appears that another concessional loan agreement, amounting to RMB 50m, was agreed upon in 2002. Reports suggest that the Chinese Exim Bank provided at least three batches of funding for the project amounting to some 1.5 billion shillings (about 18 million US dollars)-- although the nature of this funding (loan, grant) is unknown.On October 24, 2002 Kenyan President Daniel arap Moi launched the construction of the Kipsigak-Serem-Shamakhokho road project. Chinese Ambassador to Kenya Du Qiwen attended the ceremony. On November 6, 2006 the Kenyan President held talks with the Chairman of the project's implementing agency China Wu Yi, who had recently completed the project before the stipulated contract period. Kenyan Foreign Affairs Minister Raphael Tuju, Trade and Industry Minister Dr. Mukhisa Kituyi and Kenya ’s ambassador to China Amb. Ruth Solitei attended the talks.(PPIAF ID 160)

description: Sinopec purchased one of the two asphalite mines for $18.6 million. This is the first Chinese firm to enter asphalite sector. The status of the project is uncertain. title: Munali Nickel Project
description: (PPIAF) In September of 2006, construction of The Enterprise nickel deposit, located at Munali, commenced. Munali is owned by Albidon, Ltd. An Offtake Agreement was signed in December of 2006 with Jinchuan Group, which includes substantial project funding commitments from Jinchuan. $35 million USD has been raised from Albidon shareholders and $5 million USD from Jinchuan Group as part of the arrangement. $60 million USD of senior debt will be provided by the European Investment Bank and Barclays Bank as a joint venture for the project; Jinchuan Group will provide an additional $20 million in subordinated debt, making their commitment total 25 million USD. Jinchuan signed another agreement in December of 2007 to purchase all of Munali's future output. The total project cost is $100 million USD, with the Chinese providing $20 million USD for the project. PPIAF-ID:449

title: Provide digital Pay-TV and broadband Internet services
description: (PPIAF-ID:232) In July 2007, Beijing-based Star Communication Network Technology Co. Ltd officially launched Star Africa Media Co. Ltd, a subsidiary in Rwanda to provide digital Pay-TV and broadband Internet services. The company constructed a wireless digital Pay-TV station based on Digital Video Broadcasting Terrestrial (DVB-T) and a laid down broadband cable in Kigali with a total investment of 20 million USD. The company started its operations in June 2009.

title: Exploration of offshore gas Block 15 within the Red Sea Basin
description: (PPIAF-ID:432) On January 17, 2010, a consortium of oil companies began exploration of offshore gas Block 15, covering an area of 28,655 sq km within the Red Sea Basin. Total cost of US$58 million over six years, with China National Petroleum Corporation (CNPC) (35%), includes Petronas (35%), Nigeria's Express Petroleum (10%); Sudan's High Tech Group (5%). and Sudan's state oil firm Sudapet (15%) part of the consortium. The end date is unknown.

title: Chalinze Water Supply Project, Phase 1
description: In 2000, a grant was extended to Tanzania from the Chinese government for phase 1 construction of the Chalinze Rural Water Supply Project. Construction began in 2001, and was completed in 2003. China Hainan International Cooperation carried out the construction. The project cost approximately 23 billion TZS. The project also included the training of local Tanzanian staff to operate the network. PPIAF-ID:278The second phase started in 2007 and is project ID#230.

title: Accra-Kumasi trunk road rehabilitation
description: (PPIAF) In 2003, China agreed to sponsor the reconstruction of the Ofankor-Nsawam dual carriage-way. The Chinese vice minister of Foreign Affairs Yang Wenchang and President John Agyekum Kufuor signed the agreement. In April of 2006, the Ofankor-Nsawam dual carriage-way was completed at opened to vehicular traffic after two years of construction. Work started in June of 2004 under an interest-free loan agreement worth $28 million USD between Ghana and China. The terms of the loan were that it would be repaid in annual installments by the Ghanaian government over a period of ten years from November of 2012 to October of 2022 with export commodities of Ghana or convertible currencies to be agreed upong by the two governments. The road, 17.4 km in length, has no restrictions to vehicular traffic. The road is part of the Accra-Kumasi trunk road rehabilitation project. The contracting firm for the project is China Railway Engineering Corporation. The project includes the construction of a 20 meter fly-over bridge over the rail line near Ofankor. The design can handle 13 tons. The construction of the road was started by the New Patriotic Party administration under former president Kufuor via Internally Generated Funds. There is a discrepancy between financial values; sources say that the cost of the project was possibly $23.190001 million USD. PPIAF-ID:143

title: Construction of wet-process smelting plant and sulfur-to-acid plant at Chambishi copper mine
description: (PPIAF) In 2006, China Nonferrous Metal Mining Group Co. Ltd. completed the Chambishi wet-process smelting plant and sulfur-to-acid plant funded by the group at Zambia's Chambishi Copper Mine. The project cost $20 million USD, with the entire commitment paid by the Chinese. title: National Fibre Backbone Project
description: (PPIAF) In 2006, Ghana signed a deal with the Chinese government for a soft loan worth $31 million USD for the construction of a national high-tech transmission backbone infrastructure. The fiber optic network will cover the whole country providing more durable and efficient common bandwidth for all communication service providers. Under the project, all regional capitals and 36 major towns would be linked by fiber optics to enhance rural telephone and internet services. The fiber optics will be linked with Kumasi and further to the north, subsequently connecting Accra. The first phase of the project, upgrading the existing fiber optic network and expanding the communications network in the southern loop, is expected to be completed in January of 2008, and the second phase, the expansion of the network to parts of northern Ghana, is expected to be completed by the end of 2008. Ghanaian Minister of Communications Albert Kan Dapaah and VP of China's Eximbank met to agree on the deal. Deputy Minister of Communication in Ghana Dr. Benjamin Aggrey Ntim was also familiar with the project. According to reports, the construction of the project started in 2006 by Chinese company Huawei Technologies, while Eximbank made available $31 million USD towards the project. The project was initiated by the Ministry of Communications at a cost of $70 million USD. As of 2011, the project was still under construction. The project was untied. PPIAF-ID:145

title: Railway Equipment Purchase
description: (PPIAF) In November of 2005, Namibian President Hifikepunye Pohama and Chinese Politburo member Li Chang Chun witnessed the signing of a 250 million Yuan concessional loan to be used for purchasing locomotives and trains for a new railway being built in the north. The loan was granted by the Export-Import Bank of China, but the trains and locomotives have already been purchased, and TransNamib will deliver the first four machines for $12 million USD each. From a report in 2008, it appears that TransNamib ultimately purchased 17 red Chinese-made locomotives in addition to the four blue ones originally purchased. However, these purchases appear to be a strain on the company because of chronic mechanical problems. The project is likely tied with mineral resources, especially uranium. PPIAF-ID: 195

title: Drill exploration wells in Tenere Oil Block
description: In 2003, China National Petroleum Corp. (CNPC) began exploration and seismological surveys in the Ténéré oil block worth $55 million USD. In 2006, the CNPC was awarded oil prospecting rights for the exploration of two blocks, the 8.6 milion acre Tenere block and the Bilma block. According to a PPIAF Consultant, the Chinese commitment for the prospecting rights is $44 million. In 2011, the CNPC drilled the Facai-1 as part of this agreement, but the well turned up dry and was plugged and abandoned in the same year. As of 2012, CNPC is still exploring for oil in the Bilma and Tenere blocks, and co-owns a refinery with the Nigerien government in Soraz The current status of this project is implementation.; PPIAF-ID:400

title: Construct transmission lines
description: (PPIAF) In 2007, China's Export-Import Bank provided a concessional loan of 370 million Yuan to the Senegalese government to construct a 30 KM 90 KV high-voltage power transmission line and 4 90/30 KV transformer substations. The total cost of the project is $70 million USD, and the Chinese are covering $48.68 million USD of the total. The contractor is Chinese state-owned CMEC. State power company Senelec has struggled because of under-investment, poor infrastructure, and lack of funding. State-owned engineering group China National Machinery and Equipment Import and Export Corporation will carry out the work. Chinese Ambassador to Senegal Lu Shaye signed the loan agreement. On January 21, 2009, the groundbreaking ceremony for a new 90 kW power transmission project was held in Dakar. The project is expected to be completed in 2015. PPIAF-ID:238

title: Construction of the Tekeze dam, in the state of Tigray in Ethiopia
description: The total cost of the construction of the 300-mw Tekeze dam in the state of Tigray in Ethiopia was $360 million (it was originally predicted to cost $224 million), with a Chinese commitment of $50 million. The dam was 185 meters tall and was developed and built by the state-owned Chinese National Water Resources and Hydropower Engineering Corporation (Sinohydro). It was also developed by Gezhouba Water and Power Group and Sur Construction Co. The dam was expected to produce 300 MW of electricity. Construction was expected to be completed in 2008, but did not finish until 2009.The dam financier is unclear. According to the World Bank, in 2002, the Export-Import Bank of China provided $50 million on concessional financing. However, a Taiwanese news source said that the China National Water Resources and Hydropower Engineering Corporation that built the dam financed it entirely. It is not clear who will play for the cost of overruns, delays, and lost revenue. See ID# 644Additional source that would not fit:http://www.addisfortune.com/Vol%2525252010%25252520No%25252520491%25252520Archive/EEPCo%25252520Gives%25252520Construction%25252520Contracts%25252520of%25252520New%25252520Power%25252520Plants%25252520to%25252520Chinese%25252520Company.htm

title: Build the e-government network
description: In 2005, Senegalese President Wade and Chinese President Hu Jintao signed a deal worth approximately $100 million USD for the building of an e-government network. Disbursements of 390 million CNY in loans and $49 million in grants were made in 2005 and 2009 respectively. The project was to be implemented by Huawei Technologies and China Machinery Engineering Corporation (CMEC). Contacts for this project include Senegalese Minister of Information Technology and Communication, Abdourahim Agne, representative the Embassy of the People’s Republic of China in Senegal, who co-chaired the ceremony, Ms. Wei Guo, the Director of the Agence de l’Informatique de l’Etat (ADIE) Tidiane Seck, Senegal’s Minister of Home Affairs, and the Senegalese Police Chief. On February 13, 2009 an agreement with ZTE Corp. was signed to build the GoTa national secured network. The project involved setting up 100,000 secured lines covering cities, towns, police, the national security department, fire, and the confidential communications sector. The military and defense departments agreed to provide independent security communication dispatch services. The GoTa trial was officially launched in Dakar in February 2008. The formal handover ceremony completed was July 10, 2009. PPIAF-ID:237

title: Construction of terminals, tower and power control center at Ollombo Airport
description: In 2007, a commitment was made as part of a China-Congo Rep. package deal. One of the projects was the construction of terminals towers, Fire-fighting centre, water and hydrogen storage, and a power control center at an airport in Ollombo. The contract value was $62.38 million, but a PPIAF consultant placed the Chinese commitment at $56 million. The total building floorage area was 18,000 sq. meters, project construction began in October 2008 and was completed. The contractor for this project was the China Jiangsu International Economic-Technical Cooperation Corporation.; PPIAF-ID:90

title: Renewable three-year bauxite exploration license
description: (PPIAF) In November of 2005, Chalco was awarded 21 bauxite prospecting licenses for an area that covers a total of area of 10,488 sq km and lies between the regions of Kindia, Mamou, Dalaba and Mali. The value of this project is $63 million USD. Completion was expected within three years. It is unclear if the project was completed. PPIAF-ID:374

title: Build a water treatment plant and the water distribution network
description: In 2007, the China Exim Bank provided a concessional loan of 63.75 million CNY for the construction of a water treatment plant and water distribution network with 29,000 connections in Mauritius. The contractor for the project was the Beijing Construction Engineering Group. The current status of this project cannot be found, as well as exact start and end dates.; PPIAF-ID:190This project may be related to the Plaines Williams sewage plant built by BCEG at project ID#1099

title: Ghana Telecom equipment supply, Phase 1
description: (PPIAF) In 2003, Ghana Telecom and Alcatel Shanghai Bell signed a $150 million USD contract to provide 650,000 telephone lines, introduce broadband services, centralize a billing system, process and improve the quality of GT's services over the following three years. Ghanaian Minister of Communications Albert Kan Dapaah, Chinese ambassador to Ghana Lu Yonjshou, CEO of GT Oystein Bjorge, and Chairman of Alcatel Shanghai Bell Yuan Xin are all familiar with the project. In December 2003, the project was suspended because of a lawsuit against GT by Malaysian G-Gom. According to reports in 2005, the project was continued with the installation of 250 radio antenna to serve about 400,000 mobile phone users. 60 Chinese engineers are participating in the project. It is still unclear if the project was completed, but it appears to be untied. There appears to be some discrepancy between the amounts, reports include $67 million USD and $79 million USD, but it is unclear exactly how the money was designated.Phase 1 of the project appears to have been completed with the help of 60 Chinese engineers. Sources confirmed that Phase 2 was beginning in 2005.(PPIAF) In 2005, Ghana Telecom signed a buyer credit agreement with Societe Generale Corporate and Investment Bank (SG CIB) worth $67 million USD. The agreement carries a maturity of 6 years. Funds will be used to upgrade and expand Ghana Telecom's networks, financing the import of equipment from Alcatel Shanghai Bell. The loan is insured by Sinosure, the Chinese export credit agency. Phase 2 of Ghana telecom project includes the supply of fixed network exchanges, mobile network equipment, and optical transfer equipment. Sinosure prevented default on this deal, after receiving preliminary notice of potential default in February 2007. There is some confusion that this might be a 50-50 Chinese-French joint venture. The total cost for Phase 2 appears to be $80 million USD, and the Chinese will commit $67 million USD. PPIAF-ID:140, 141

title: The electrization of rural areas in Ghana
description: (PPIAF) In 2006, China agreed to the electrization of rural areas in Ghana, a deal worth $81 million USD. The Chinese state-owned Export-Import Bank will be funding the $81 million USD, but the project is worth $90 million USD in total. Construction will be designated to the China International Water & Electric Corporation. This project will link 580 communities in 7 provinces to the national power grid. Construction began in August of 2007, following the completion of site survey and design work. It appears that the project is still under construction. PPIAF-ID:142

title: Rehabilitation of Luanda Railway, Phase 1
description: (PPIAF) In 2002, China Construction Bank and Ex-Im Bank financed the Phase 1 Rehabilitation of the Luanda Railway. The railway is 444 km long, and consists of a railway, bridges, and stations along the route. In addition, there are some telecommunication and signal works. The Chinese commitment is $90 million USD. Construction commenced in October of 2003 and was expected to be completed in August of 2008. The project was inaugurated in September of 2008. PPIAF-ID:37

title: Chambishi West Ore Body Project
description: (PPIAF) In 2007, CNMC's subsidiary Non-ferrous China Africa, announced its investment of $100 million USD in the Chambishi copper mine in Zambia. The project was scheduled to be completed within three years, with an estimated reserve of 34 million tons of copper with a grade of 2.03 percent. It is expected to produce 1 million tons of copper annually in the next 25 years. It appears that the project may have been completed. PPIAF-ID:452

title: Development of Musonoi copper and cobalt mine
description: A contract for the development of a copper and cobalt mine with a planned annual production of 30,000 tons of copper and 5,000 tons of cobalt was signed between the China National Overseas Engineering Corp. (COVEC) and state-owned DRCongolese Gecamines on August 8, 2005. According to the terms of the contract, Gecamines was responsible for providing information and transferring mining rights to COVEC, and COVEC was responsible for funding and conducting studies for geological prospecting, comply with environmentally sound mining techniques, provide mining equipment, construct metallurgical plants, pay an entry fee to Gecamines of 3 million USD, and to mobilize funding for the entire mining operation. Survey work started on the site on August 10, 2007. The initial participation in capital was listed at 73% for COVEC and 27% non-dilutable for Gecamines. Gecamines was also entitled to royalties equal to 1.5% of gross sales revenue for the first three years of production, and 2% for the remaining life of the project. COVEC was reported to have employed 30 nationally Congolese employees. After an analysis of the partnership in 2007, a Gecamines commission declared that because no feasibility study had been produced in a reasonable time, and COVEC had failed to produce evidence that the contract had been approved by the Chinese government, that COVEC must give Gecamines a loan of 60 million USD to recoup its losses. The Commission left the possibility of re-starting the contract open, but terminated it in what was called a final report on the contract. Chinese Commitment: USD 100 Million; PPIAF-ID:345

title: Construction of the Chambishi Copper Smelter (CCS)
description: (PPIAF) The Chambishi Copper Smelter was a new Zambian partnership between CNMC (60%), which had been operating the Chambishi Copper Mine since 1998, and YNCIG (40%), China's third largest copper producer and smelter operator. The signing ceremony was in the presence of President Levy Patrick Mwanawasa, Chinese Ambassador to Zambia Li Baodong, and Zambian Ambassador to China David Saviye. Construction of the Chambishi Copper Smelter commenced in December 2006 and was to utilize ISAsmelt technology. The smelter was expected to begin production in late 2008 and produce 150,000 tonnes of copper metal per year. The total cost of the project was $200 million USD, and the Chinese committed to $100 million USD. The project was a joint venture between CNMC and the Yunnan Copper Industry Group Co. Ltd. PPIAF-ID:447

title: Oilfield Block 3113 exploration
description: In 2007, Sino Union Petroleum and Chemical International paid Golden Nova Holdings US$103 million for a 93% stake in Madagascar Energy. The company aimed to undertake an oil exploration project in Madagascar's Block 3113, which covers 8,320 square kilometers. The Chinese funded foreign direct investment Madagascar Energy was required to invest at least US $17.5 million on oil exploration. In return, the company held the rights to eight years of oil and gas exploration, 25 years of oil production rights and 35 years of natural gas production on block 3113. Madagascar Energy received an entitlement to 45-73% of the profit from Block 3113. The rest of the profit would go to the Madagascar government.In 2009 the company had progressed significantly in its exploration of Oilfield Block 3113. The exploration looked optimistic for future earnings, and Madagascar Energy judged the field an oil and gas condensate field. Wikileaks reveals that in January 2010, the Chinese firm Yanchang bought 15 percent of Sino Union (look to #1017). Kaiyuan then acquired five percent of Sino Union shares in February 2010. Blocks 3113 and 2104 have estimated oil reserves of 5.6 billion barrels and natural gas reserves of 66 billion cubic meters, according to a statement issued by Sunpec.As of April 2012, Yanchang reported that two of three wells had been drilled. The current status of the project is still implementation.PPIAF-ID:386

title: Construction of Garri (Qarre) I station at El-Gaili (Al Jaily)
description: (PPIAF-ID:252) On November 16, 2000, the Sudanese Energy Minister Awad Ahmed al-Jaz and the Harbin Electricity Company signed an agreement for the Chinese company to build the first phase of the Garri (Qarre) Combined Cycle Power Plant in at El-Gaili (Al Jaily), Sudan. The China Exim Bank financed the project with 127.5 million USD. The Chinese company will own the plant and the Sudanese government will buy the produced electricity. It includes a 100-km electric transportation line, the construction of a new substation and the expansion of an old one. China's Foreign Minister Li Zhaoxing and Sudanese Electricity Minister Ali Temim Fertak inaugurated the Qarre I plant on January 5, 2004. As part of the deal, the Sudanese government agreed to pay 18 million USD for the completion of the el-Jaili refinery which was to provide the gas for the power plant. Additional source:http://www.jamestown.org/programs/chinabrief/single/?tx_ttnews%25252525252525252525252525252525255Btt_news%25252525252525252525252525252525255D=3898 tx_ttnews%25252525252525252525252525252525255BbackPid%25252525252525252525252525252525255D=195 no_cache=1

title: Investment in Heglig and Unity oil fields (Blocks 1, 2 and 4)
description: (PPIAF-ID:434) In 2001, Greater Nile Petroleum Operating Company (GNPOC) announced its decision to invest 360 million USD in the Heglig and Unity oilfields (Blocks 1,2 and 4 ) in 2001. China National Petroleum Corp. (CNPC) owns 40% of GNPOC, making CNPC's investment 144 million USD. Project began in 1998. The current status and start and end dates are unknown.

title: Rehabilitate Brazaville Airport project (Maya-Maya international airport)
description: As part of a China-Congo package deal, an agreement was signed to renovate the Maya-Maya International Airport in Brazzaville. The project included the construction of two terminals, two landing strips, and a transformer sub-station. The total cost is $160 million, and is currently being implemented by the Weihai International Economic and Technical Cooperation Co. Ltd. (WIETC). With these improvements, the Congolese government hopes to accomodate 2 million passengers a year. Construction is expected to be completed by the end of 2012.; PPIAF-ID:91

title: The No. 1 and 2 ring roads of the Angola City
description: (PPIAF) The No. 1 and No. 2 ring roads of the Angola City appear to have been assisted by a Chinese commitment of $170 million USD. China's Export-Import Bank and the China Machinery Engineering Corporation (CMEC) seem to have some connection to the project. It is unclear what the commitment year is, and further details have not been found. PPIAF-ID:6

title: National Rural Telephony Project (NRPT) Phase 1 and 2
description: In 2002, Huawei Technologies signed contracts for rural telephone service across Nigeria for the connection of 218 rural communities to the Public Switched Telephone Network. The first phase of the project covered 117 local governments, and the second phase 125 local council areas. The first and second phases were funded by a $200 million Export-Import Bank of China loan. The project was expected to begin in 2003, created 200,000 telephone lines, and was aimed at providing voice, video, and data telecommunication equipment. Some of the construction contracts were awarded to Shanghai Bell and ZTE. At last record, the project was in implementation.The third phase of this project is in ID#28482.

title: Chinese firm snaps up stake in Zimbabwe ferrochrome producer
description: On September 19, 2007, the Chinese state-owned company Sinosteel Corporation signed an agreement to acquire a majority 92% stake worth US$200 million in the Mauritius-Zimbabwean company Zimasco Consolidated Enterprises (ZCE) with options to acquire the remaining 8% over the following two-and-a-half years; Sinosteel did not formally acquire its share in Zimasco until December 13, 2007. Also part of the deal, Sinosteel would indirectly own ZCE's subsidiary, Zimasco Holdings: a ferrochrome producer and exporter based directly in Zimbabwe. Sinosteel originally planned to purchase a 50% stake in Zimasco but that progressed over time to 67%, 73%, and then the final total of 92% in December. All of Zimasco's staff and management will remain in place while Sinosteel will acquire Zimasco's iron-ore mines and smelting plants in Zimbabwe. Sinosteel Corporation's representative in the deal was the general manager of the company's international cooperation department, Jiang Baocai.As of 2010, Zimasco Holdings was renamed as Sinosteel Zimbabwe Chrome, but remains a wholly-owned subsidiary of Sinosteel Corporation. It is the largest ferrochrome producer in Zimbabwe with major plants operating in Kwekwe and Shurugwi, Zimbabwe.

title: Sudan Telecom purchasing equipment from ZTE
description: (PPIAF-ID:257) On November 24, 2005, China's Exim Bank signed a MOU with Sudan Telecom to loan the Sudanese company 200 million USD for the purchase of communication equipment from ZTE. On May 30, 2006, a rumor was reported saying that Sudan Telecom had been unhappy with some of the equipment and would request a cancellation of the contract. ZTE declared it merely a rumor. Nothing was reported on it again. However, it does confirm that the MOU was completed. The exact end date is unknown.

title: Purchase of 50 percent stake in oil block from Canadian EnCana (Permit H)
description: In 2007, CNPC (China National Petroleum Corp) bought 50% rights in a convention and permit H and 7 sedimentary basins (54 million acres) from EnCana for $202.5 million. (PPIAF) Canada based EnCana sold its oil assets in Chad to CNPC including the 50% rights in a convention and permit H and 7 sedimentary basins (54 million acres). title: Construction of a new international airport at Nouakchott
description: (PPIAF) In 2005, the Mauritanian government and the China Metallurgial Corporation (MCC) signed an agreement to construct a new international airport at Nouakchott, the country's capital. The agreement provides that MCC will provide a loan of $136 million USD to Mauritania, covering about 80% of the total cost of the project, the remainder to be paid by the Mauritanian government. The loan includes a three year grace period, after which the loan will be paid off in 16 years at an interest rate of 3% per annum. The construction of the project will be completed within 36 months. Mauritania will repay the loan largely in iron ore. PPIAF-ID:185

title: Develop the Kalumbwe-Myunga copper-cobalt mine
description: In 2005, China National Overseas Engineering Corp (COVEC) signed a preliminary agreement with Congo's MKM Co to develop a copper and cobalt mine referred to as the Kalumbwe-Myunga in the Kolwezi District of Katanga Province. In the joint-venture agreement, COVEC holds a 71% stake while MKM holds a 29% stake. According to unlisted PPIAF sources, the project required a total investment of $39 million, but also stated that the total project cost and Chinese commitment were both $270 million. A September 2008 article reported that COVEC had extended a $60 million line of credit to MKM to use to fund their share of the development. The project is expected to produce 8,700 tons per year of copper and 926 tons per year of cobalt. An October 2011 paper reported that the mine is currently operational. The exact start date, end date, and definite amount are still unknown.

title: Heglig and Unity fields (Blocks 1, 2 and 4) 2005 investment commitments
description: (PPIAF-ID:431) In 2005, Greater Nile Petroleum Operating Company (GNPOC) announced its decision to invest 700 million USD in the Heglig and Unity oilfields (Blocks 1,2 and 4 ) in 2005 for exploration, development and production. China National Petroleum Corp. (CNPC) owns 40% of GNPOC, making CNPC's investment 280 million USD. The current status and start and end dates are unknown.

title: Construction of Papalanto Power Gas Turbine Power Plant, in Ogun
description: In 2002, Shandong No. 3 Electric Power Construction Company (SEPCO III) won a $360 million contract for the Papalanto plant. The total cost of the project was $359.71 million, with a Chinese commitment of $297.75 million funded by the Export-Import Bank of China. Additional funding may have come from the Nigeria Power and Steel Department. The plant was put into operation in 2007. Nigerian former president Obasanjo stated in 2007 that Papalanto, as well as Chinese-financed Omotosho, were generating power for Nigeria's electricity grid in May 2007. The project was expanded, with SEPCO III securing both the original and expansion contracts, and completion was scheduled for June 2010. ; PPIAF-ID:209
