title: 400 five-roomed houses at Arda-Transau
description: In 2011, plans began to construct over USD 1 million of infrastructure for displaced residents in Arda-Transau. 400, 5 roomed houses were constructed, as well as a primary and secondary school. construction of primary and secondary schools are in progress. The implementing agency for the project was Anjin Investments. Contacts for this project include Governor and Resident Minister, Chris Mushowe. The project was completed in 2011. The flow type for this project is unknown.

title: Financial Cooperation Agreement
description: On September 28, 2011, the Development Bank of South Africa and the China Development Bank signed a financial cooperation agreement. The agreement was for $2.5 US billion. The agreement provided that the two banks will invest in mining, infrastructure, transport, communication, energy, and agricultural projects in the future. Information on whether or not any money has been invested in these types of projects is unclear.

title: Mabubas Hydroelectric Dam
description: In July 2009, work began on the repair of the Mabubas hydroelectric dam by the Guangxi Hydroelectric Construction Bureau (GHCB). The dam had a capacity of 17 mw, and the repairs will up that to 26.8 mw. On May 14, 2012, the governor of northern Bengo province, João Bernardo de Miranda, announced the re-opening of the Mabubas hydro-electric dam. The estimated costs to the Chinese company were $21.7 million over the years it took to complete. Reports said that the project was financed by a Chinese company called Kanazuri Electric. Searches for information on the company were unsuccessful.

title: National Rural Telephony Project (NRPT) Phase 3
description: In 2004, Nigeria negotiated another $100 loan backed by a loan guarantee from the Chinese government for the third phase of a National Rural Telephony project, which covered over 150 local government areas. Implementing organizations for this phase include Shanghai Bell, Huawei, and ZTE. At last record, the project was in implementation.The first two phases of this project are in ID#163.

title: Humanitarian Aid
description: On October 31, 2007, China signed an agreement in Kenya to provide $1.5 million in aid to Somalia. The agreement was signed by Somali President Abdullahi Yusuf and Chinese Ambassador in Kenya, Zhang Ming. It includes $500,000 in humanitarian aid.The status of the projects is uncertain.

title: Construction of Leather Factory
description: On November 4, 2010, China's Xinxiang Kuroda Minliang Leather Co. announced it would open a $67 million leather factory in Ethiopia on November 24. Xinxiang financed 55 percent of the project, with the remainder coming from the China-Africa Development Fund, according to the Chinese embassy in Ethiopia.

title: John Agyekum Kufuor Catholic Information Technology Institute
description: In 2008, the ICT education centre, named after President Kufuor, was formally inaugurated. The institute, aimed at facilitating the extension of ICT services to underprivileged rural areas, was jointly financed by government of Ghana through the HIPC initiative with support from the the Nkwatakese community, the Catholic Church, the United Nations Development Programme (UNDP), and ZTE Ghana Limited, a Chinese telecommunication company. Known as JAK CITI, the fixed with 50 computers donated by ZTE, is projected to provide training in basic ICT skills, provide business support for local business and also provide internet connectivity to the community. The centre is worth 500,000 Ghana cedis, but the Chinese funding beyond the 50 computers is unknown.

title: Jiangsu Province invests in Pesticide Plant
description: Jiangsu Province invested in a pesticide manufacturer outside Kibaha, Tanzania. This is potentially part of Project #1825 of seven investments within the country made by the province.

title: ZESCO Fibre-optic lines Phase II
description: A contract for implementing Phase II of the fibre project was signed between ZESCO and ZTE Corporation of China on 30th July, 2010. The cost of Phase II is US$43.9 million exclusive of taxes. ZESCO has already made an advance payment of about US$6.9 million to ZTE. The balance of US$37 million is to be financed with a loan from the Bank of China. Along with phase I, this project represents 5,300km of optic fibre network covering 46 districts, including rural districts and two international connections to Namibia and Tanzania. Zesco’s director of transmission, Christopher Mubemba commented on the project.

title: FAO Tripartite Agricultural Agreement
description: In first 2006 and then again in 2010, China, Sierra Leone and FAO signed South-South Cooperation tripartite agreements under the China-FAO US$30 million Trust Fund. Over 20 cooperants were fielded in the past and another 22 agricultural experts and technicians will be fielded in 2011. Areas of activities and applied technologies are paddy rice plantation, vegetable/crop production, aquaculture, livestock, agro-forestry, irrigation, etc.

title: Loan to West Africa Development Bank
description: In 2004, China made its first capital contribution to the West Africa Development Bank in the form of an 8 billion FCFA loan. This loan made China the second largest partner of the Bank behind France. The loan specifics are unknown. This project was discovered from sources for Project #19671 in which the China Development Bank provided the loan; it can be assumed that the bank provided this one as well.
sector: Trade, Tourism, Banking and Financial Services
